Suggested edit: Apart from measurable psychological factors, like fatigue and stress leading to symptoms such as headaches and concentration problems, interpreters would complain about the feeling of 'not being there' (Mouzourakis 2006), not having the possibility of getting the right feel for the situation and not being able to interact directly with the other participants of the event. These psychological symptoms were mainly attributed to the limited view of the speaker and the audience.

As for cognition, the cognitive load is also being influenced significantly by every alteration of the setting (Moser-Mercer 2005). Such a load is generated by additional, or at least altered, receptive and productive tasks related to the sub-processes of listening to a source text, processing its content and re-producing that content in the target language.
